awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Subatomic-Scale Quantum Matter Data Using Machine Learning Tools
awd_abstract_narration:
A central goal of modern quantum physics is to search for new systems and technological paradigms that utilize quantum mechanical aspects of matter rather than being limited by them. In particular, there is an active search for new materials that exhibit surprising physical properties because of strong interaction between individual electrons that leads to strong correlations in the motion of electrons and as a result, to strongly correlated quantum matter. The study of Strongly Correlated Quantum Matter (SCQM) has reached a tipping point through intense efforts over the last decade that have led to vast quantities of experimental data. The next breakthrough in the field will come from relating these experimental data to theoretical models using tools of data science. However, data-driven challenges in SCQM require a fundamentally new data science approaches for two reasons: first, quantum mechanical imaging is probabilistic; and second, inference from data should be subject to fundamental laws of physics. Hence the new data-driven challenges in the field of SCQM requires "Growing Convergent Research" and "Harnessing the Data Revolution", two of NSF's Ten Big Ideas. 

The objective of the project is to develop and disseminate machine learning (ML) tools that can serve as a two-way highway connecting the data revolution in SCQM experiments at sub-atomic scale to a fundamental theoretical understanding of SCQM. The specific goals are: (1) Develop interpretable ML tools for position space image data; (2) Develop unsupervised ML tools for momentum space scattering data; (3) Design new imaging modality guided by the insight gained from ML; and (4) Integrate ML tools with in-operando human interface to the Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) beamline. Goals (1) and (2) are within reach, while (3) and (4) are more ambitious visions for scaling up to a future institute that can involve more academic institutions and scattering experiment facilities nationwide. 

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the project was to develop and disseminate machine learning tools that can serve as a two-way highway connecting the data revolution in strongly correlated quantum matter (SCQM) experiments at sub-atomic scale to their theoretical understanding. Below are highlights the projects.  

  • Correlator Convolutional Neural Networks: An Interpretable Architecture for

Image-like Quantum Matter Data

We developed an intrinsically interpretable architecture that uses physically meaningful non-linearity, correlation covolutional neural network (CCNN)[i] to analyze image-like quantum matter data to extract new information. CCNN addresses a fundamental question of how to extract new information from image-like quantum matter data. As its first application, we applied CCNN to snapshots of quantum gas microscopy (QGM) data.

  • Harnessing Interpretable and Unsupervised ML to Address Big Data from Modern X-ray Diffraction

We introduced an unsupervised and interpretable ML approach: X-ray Temperature Clustering X-TEC[ii]. X-TEC is surprisingly effective, very fast to train, and robust in practice. X-TEC analyzed 8 TB of data spanning 15,000 Brillouin zones in just 10 minutes and revealed the order parameter and fluctuations in pyrochlore metal Cd2Re2O7. The selection rule revealed the atomic-scale detail of the Goldstone mode fluctuations. We established for the first time that key insights into orders and fluctuations that are subtly encoded in voluminous modern X-ray diffraction (XRD) can be expeditiously uncovered through interdisciplinary investments in data analytics infrastructure.

  • Attention-based quantum tomography (AQT)

We proposed and demonstrated a quantum state reconstruction using an attention mechanism-based generative network that learns the mixed-state density matrix of a noisy quantum state[iii]. AQT is based on the classical ML model which is designed to learn long-range correlations in natural language sentences. We have demonstrated that AQT outperforms earlier neural network-based quantum-state reconstruction methods and that AQT can accurately reconstruct the density matrix associated with a noisy quantum state experimentally realized in an IBM-Q quantum computer.

  • Quantum Approximate Bayesian Computation for NMR Model Inference

We  proposed a quantum-classical hybrid approach to super-polynomial speed-up in performing inference on 1D $^1$H-NMR spectroscopy through Quantum Approximate Bayesian Computation (qABC)[iv]. Despite being one of the most powerful analytical techniques available to biology and a key tool in metabolomics, the difficulties in its interpretation hinder clinical and industrial adoption of NMR. The challenge is two-fold. First, the likelihood is completely intractable, as it can only be computed by performing a quantum simulation. Second, even when the likelihood can be evaluated, the multi-model nature of typical spectral functions results in a complex optimization landscape. qABC solves both problems by performing a hybrid quantum-classical computation. It opens up an entire new application for near-term quantum computers.

Intellectual Merit:

The project has propelled us beyond the tipping point in our understanding of the SCQM through the two-way data science highway between the SCQM experiments and theoretical models. For position space QGM data, CCNN enabled an objective hypothesis testing. Moreover, the importance of higher-order correlations revealed by CCNN is guiding the design of future imaging experiments. For the momentum space scattering data X-TEC is accelerating discovery from a high-volume scattering data set. X-TEC analyzes 10 TB of data in 10 minutes, to discover order parameters and their fluctuations without presupposed knowledge.  X-TEC can revolutionize the XRD research modality.

Broader Impacts:

The project led to the team’s collaborations  with two broad communities: SCQM researchers using Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, and  next-generation SCQM researchers. We incorporated the larger community in science and engineering through online seminars, workshops, and tutorials. Moreover, the code we released is keeping the community abreast of the cutting-edge developments. The Machine Learning for SCQM summer school we ran during summer 2021 offered hands-on learning experiences to the next generation of SCQM researchers.


[i] Cole Miles et al., “Correlator Convolutional Neural Networks as an Interpretable Architecture for Image-like Quantum Matter Data,” Nature Communications 12, no. 1 (June 23, 2021): 3905, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-23952-w.

[ii] Jordan Venderley et al., “Harnessing Interpretable and Unsupervised Machine Learning to Address Big Data from Modern X-Ray Diffraction,” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 119, no. 24 (June 14, 2022): e2109665119, https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2109665119.

[iii] Peter Junghwa Cha et al., “Attention-Based Quantum Tomography,” Machine Learning: Science and Technology 3 (November 23, 2021): 01LT01, https://doi.org/10.1088/2632-2153/ac362b.

[iv] Dries Sels et al., “Quantum Approximate Bayesian Computation for NMR Model Inference,” Nature Machine Intelligence 2, no. 7 (July 2020): 396–402, https://doi.org/10.1038/s42256-020-0198-x.
